summary: filovirus infection can cause a life threatening hemorrhagic fever (e.g. Ebola virus disease, EVD) in non-human primates and humans, with case-fatality rates of up to 90%. before 2013, filovirus outbreaks in human populations were restricted to remote areas in central africa and were associated with less than 500 cases. bats are considered a natural reservoir for filoviruses from which these viruses might be transmitted to humans either directly or via intermediate hosts. role of bats as a natural reservoir for filoviruses is supported by the detection of filoviruses in multiple, geographically dispersed bat species. the receptor binding domain (RBD) and a mucin-like domain (MLD) are found in all filovirus GPs. processing of EBOV-GP by these enzymes is dispensable for robust viral spread in cell culture and in the host.
